events.name: ONLINE: First Tampa Bay Google Cloud Event!
events.description:
Online Zoom link has been added to this event.

Come join us as we kick off the first event for the new Tampa Bay GDG (Google Developers Group) Cloud meetup! Come learn more about GCP and how local companies are leveraging the Google cloud.

Alan Ranciato (Google Cloud Customer Engineer) will discuss GCP and the innovation that Google has introduced to the cloud. Jack Newman, Google Cloud Account Executive) then will join Alan and discuss various success stories companies have had in the Tampa Bay area while leveraging the Google cloud.

About the speakers:

Alan Ranciato - Google Cloud Customer Engineer. A 30 year resident of Tampa Bay. Over 20 years of experience in Enterprise application development and architecture with a specialty in DevOps strategy and Cloud architecture. Holds Google Cloud certifications as a Cloud Architect, Data Engineer, Cloud Developer, and DevOps Engineer.

Jack Newman - Google Cloud Account Executive . 3 years at Google Cloud in account management. Over 10 years of experience in technology sales roles. Passion for helping customers build solutions. Recent transplant to the Tampa Bay area.

upcoming.name: Microservices on Google Cloud - POSTPONED
upcoming.description:
*** POSTPONED due to COVID-19 ***
****************************************

As a company, we wanted our product to be at its best both from customer experience standpoint and an architecture perspective. Until recently, all best practices and recommendations were pointing to 3-tier architecture, and that is how our monolith .NET applications were born.

However, scalability issues can arise in this type of architecture. That set our company us on a quest to find new architecture patterns and associated technologies that would solve this problem and solve it quickly. In less than 3 months we were able to adopt Kubernetes (GKE) and a micro-services architecture, which allowed us to achieve 1000x scalability, rapid reaction to spikes, all while in the same time reducing DB load and even cost.

In this talk, I want to share steps, challenges, solutions, surprises and issues that we saw during this transition. I hope that our experience would be useful for those who are on the same path now, planning to start on it soon, or just curious about Kubernetes. While it was a .NET application in our case, most things are applicable to any monolith application.

Speaker bio:
Artem Nikulchenko works as a Chief Software Architect in Teamwork Commerce (leading company in the space of retail management solutions that provides a completely mobile, cloud-based solution that is used by retail chains in USA, Canada, Brazil, Mexico, Japan, China, Europe and Great Britain) and part-time Associate Professor in Kharkiv National Technical University. He has 10+ years of experience in architecture, software development and management of development teams. His previous employment includes IBM Research Lab in Zurich, DB Best Technologies etc. He has a PhD in Computer Science and 20+ scientific papers published in the area of supply chain management. Outside of his main job, he actively participates in education projects as co-owner of IT Univer (ituniver.com) and IT Univer for Students (ituniver.net), and organizer of a Google Developer Group.

organizers.name: Sage
organizers.bio: I am a Human Being. I have many varied interests, including my most passionate; science, physics, technology, sociology & environmental concerns. I currently work in IT as a web developer and solution architect.

group_profile.intro: I am a passionate cloud advocate with a strong focus on bringing our technology community closer together.
